name: knot
content:
knot

noun
 
/nɒt/
 
/nɑːt/
Idioms
jump to other results

    in string/rope

  1. ​
    enlarge image
    a join made by tying together two pieces or ends of string, rope, etc.
    • to tie a knot
    • Tie the two ropes together with a knot.
    • Tie a knot in the rope.
    • Sailors had to know lots of different knots.
    see also granny knot, Gordian knot, reef knot, slip knot, square knot, Windsor knot
    Oxford Collocations Dictionaryadjective
    • loose
    • tight
    • tangled
    • …
    verb + knot
    • do
    • tie
    • undo
    • …
    preposition
    • knot in
    phrases
    • a knot in your stomach
    See full entry
    2.

    of hair

  2. ​a way of twisting hair into a small round shape at the back of the head
    • She had her hair in a knot.
    Topics Appearancec2
  3. ​a tight mass in something such as hair or wool, where it has become twisted together
    • hair full of knots and tangles
    4.

    in wood

  4. ​a hard round spot in a piece of wood where there was once a branch

    5. group of people

  5. ​a small group of people standing close together
    • Little knots of people had gathered at the entrance.
    6.

    of muscles

  6. ​a tight, hard feeling in the stomach, throat, etc. caused by nerves, anger, etc.
    • My stomach was in knots.
    • I could feel a knot of fear in my throat.
    7.

    speed of boat/plane

  7. ​a unit for measuring the speed of boats and aircraft; one nautical mile per hourTopics Maths and measurementc2
    8. Word OriginOld English cnotta, of West Germanic origin; related to Dutch knot.
Idioms
at a rate of knots
  1. ​(British English, informal) very quickly
    • She's getting through her winnings at a rate of knots.

tie somebody/yourself (up) in knots
  1. ​(informal) to become or make somebody very confused
    • I got myself tied up in knots when I tried to explain the legal system to them.
tie the knot
  1. ​(informal) to get married
See knot in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary

name: knot
content:
knot

verb
 
/nɒt/
 
/nɑːt/
Verb Forms
present simple I / you / we / they knot
 
/nɒt/
 
/nɑːt/
he / she / it knots
 
/nɒts/
 
/nɑːts/
past simple knotted
 
/ˈnɒtɪd/
 
/ˈnɑːtɪd/
past participle knotted
 
/ˈnɒtɪd/
 
/ˈnɑːtɪd/
-ing form knotting
 
/ˈnɒtɪŋ/
 
/ˈnɑːtɪŋ/
Idioms
jump to other results

    tie with knot

  1. ​[transitive] knot something to fasten something with a knot or knots
    • He carefully knotted his tie.
    • She wore a scarf loosely knotted around her neck.
    Extra Examples
    • I knotted the ropes together securely.
    • She knotted the scarf loosely around her neck.
    Oxford Collocations Dictionaryadverb
    • securely
    • tightly
    • loosely
    • …
    preposition
    • around
    • round
    See full entry
    2.

    bend into knot

  2. ​[intransitive] to become twisted into a knot synonym tangle
  3. ​[transitive] knot something to twist hair into a particular shape
    • She wore her hair loosely knotted on top of her head.
    Topics Appearancec2

    4. muscles

  4. ​[intransitive, transitive] knot (something) if muscles, etc. knot or something knots them, they become hard and painful because of fear, excitement, etc.
    • She felt her stomach knot with fear.
    Topics Feelingsc2
    5. Word OriginOld English cnotta, of West Germanic origin; related to Dutch knot.
Idioms
get knotted
  1. ​(British English, informal, slang) a rude way of telling somebody to go away or of telling them that you are annoyed with them
See knot in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: knot

name: reef knot
content:
reef knot

noun
 
/ˈriːf nɒt/
 
/ˈriːf nɑːt/
(especially British English)
(North American English usually square knot)
jump to other results
  1. ​a type of double knot (= a join made by tying together two pieces or ends of rope, etc.) that will not come undone easily
Check pronunciation: reef knot

name: slip knot
content:
slip knot

noun
 
/ˈslɪp nɒt/
 
/ˈslɪp nɑːt/
jump to other results
  1. ​a knot that can slide easily along the rope, etc. on which it is tied, in order to make the loop or rope tighter or looser
See slip knot in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: slip knot

name: granny knot
content:
granny knot

noun
 
/ˈɡræni nɒt/
 
/ˈɡræni nɑːt/
jump to other results
  1. ​an untidy double knot like reef knot tied the wrong way, which comes undone easily compare reef knot
See granny knot in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary

name: square knot
content:
square knot

noun
 
/ˈskweə nɒt/
 
/ˈskwer nɑːt/
(North American English)
(also reef knot especially in British English)
jump to other results
  1. ​a type of double knot (= a join made by tying together two pieces or ends of rope, etc.) that will not come undone easily

name: Gordian knot
content:
Gordian knot

noun
 
/ˌɡɔːdiən ˈnɒt/
 
/ˌɡɔːrdiən ˈnɑːt/
jump to other results
  1. ​a very difficult or impossible task or problem
    • to cut/untie the Gordian knot (= to solve a problem by taking action)
    Word Originmid 16th cent.: from the legend that Gordius, king of Gordium in Persia, tied an intricate knot and prophesied that whoever untied it would become the ruler of Asia. It was cut through with a sword by the Greek leader Alexander the Great.
See Gordian knot in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: Gordian knot

/ˌwɪnzər ˈnɑːt/
jump to other results
  1. ​a large loose knot in a man’s tie

name: the Sealed Knot
content:
the Sealed Knot

 
/ðə ˌsiːld ˈnɒt/
 
/ðə ˌsiːld ˈnɑːt/
jump to other results
  1. ​a British society, formed in 1968, which performs historical scenes, especially from battles of the English Civil War. Members dress as soldiers of the period and usually perform where the original battles took place. The organization also works as an educational charity in schools.
Check pronunciation: the Sealed Knot
